Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2008 04:34PM talbrig13 wrote: runny nose....twitching eye.....constipation....all of it is "normal"....the new normal.  But they go away once you are done.    I did 10 TCH and then finished the year with Herceptin.  Hang in there!

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2009 05:46PM talbrig13 wrote: I took my lasix any time my fingers felt too swollen.  The onc prescribed potassium  to take with it, as lasix depletes potassium.
Posts.Title: When to take lasix? rayhope talbrig13

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 04:50AM talbrig13 wrote: Hi Peggy, I did Carboplatin, taxotere & herceptin.  I had a severe allergic reaction to the tax the 1st treatment.  Exactly like you...red  face, heart racing, bone pain.  they tried it 3 times that day then stopped and gave me a dose of cytoxan instead.   From then on I premedicated myself the night before with Decadron.  And then I was okay.   Did you take any decadron the night before the taxotere?  Maybe that is what you need.  Can't answer about the AC and number of treatments.   I stayed away from that due to heart issues also.  I did 10 treatments of carboplatin and herceptin, one of cytoxan and 9 of taxotere.   My onc thought that was okay.   I know that doesn't answer you question completely, but maybe a help.  Good luck to you

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2008 12:03PM talbrig13 wrote: yup...definitely the steroids.   I did 10 TCH Feb 07 to July 07....gained about 10 pounds.   Be careful of that!   If you eat fresh fruit and veggies...make sure you wash it well, since your immune system in compromised, you don't want to pick up a nasty bug! I craved carbs....bread, pretzels, chips etc....stuff I don't normally eat.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2007 12:59PM talbrig13 wrote: Yes, herceptin is an IV. I take premeds....2 Tylenol and 1 Benedryl before I go. They draw labs and order the meds. If they are running on time it taked abour 1 1/2 hours. Last time I had to wait for a chemo room chair, so it was 3 1/2 hours. If you have already had Herceptin, it runs for a half hour. If it is your first one, they slow it down to an hour. Hope that helps!

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2008 09:26AM talbrig13 wrote: OncoType is a special test done just to test for chances of recurrance.   It is only good for ER+, node negative tumors.   Looks like yours would qualify.   The test is done by Genomic Health and costs about $3800....not all insurances cover it.  Mine did not.   It is used to help you and the onc decide if chemo treatment will give you enough benefit to be worth the side effects.   If you have a low score the onc would decide against chemo, a high score you would do chemo....intermediate you make the call.   You can google Oncotype to read all about it.   If you have already decided you need chemo, then maybe it is not necessary.  My oncotype score was 47....high....so I did chemo even though my onc had been "on the fence" thinking I was very low risk, having caught the tumor early.  Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2010 06:40PM talbrig13 wrote: The oncotype test is done a a tissue sample from your surgery, of the actual tumor.  They test the genes of the tumor itself.  Look at genomic.com to get more info.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 06:16PM talbrig13 wrote: I had 10 tx and a year of Herceptin with a port.  If I had to do it over (hopefully NOT!)  I would not bother with a port.   It never worked right and ended up having the last few Herceptins by IV in my arm anyway.   The chemo nurses are "experts" at putting in IVs...Good Luck and Best Wishes.
Posts.Title: has anyone had IV chemo? Mandy1313 talbrig13

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 06:18AM talbrig13 wrote: I worked full time in a bank with the public coming in and coughing and hacking around me.  I was the only one on my staff who did not get colds, flu that year.    I kept germx on my desk and would wipe off my desk and pens etc with it, especially if someone was sick around me.  You would be surprised how many people come into a setting like that and hack and cough and say something like they just called off sick from work because they are soooo sick!    Well, stay out of my life! Anyway, you can do it...just be diligent about hand washing, keep kleenex and germx around.
Posts.Title: Working while doing chemo ? JustJudi talbrig13

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2007 05:33PM talbrig13 wrote: I had lumpectomy Dec 28th. Waited for my oncotype test, which didn't come back until the last week of January. Started chemo Feb 8th...exactly 6 weeks from surgery. Oncotype was 47. Did 10 biweekly doses of carboplatin, taxotere and herceptin. Worked fulltime which was draining, but "doable" (our favorite word!). Am now donw to my last week of radiation. Almost done! Best of luck to you. We are all here to listen when you need a friend.
